courseDescription: An introductory, non-sequential course for non-biology majors with laboratory. This course concentrates on major biological concepts concerning molecular biology, cellular biology, cellular reproduction, energetics, and organismal biology. Laboratory activities enhance understanding of core biological topics.  Cannot be substituted for BIOL 121N and BIOL 122N or for BIOL 123N and BIOL 124N.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating scientific findings to non-biology majors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying biological concepts to real-world scenarios

courseDescription: An introductory, non-sequential course for nonbiology majors with laboratory. This course concentrates on major biological concepts involving classical and molecular genetics, biotechnology, evolution, and ecology. Laboratory activities enhance understanding of core biological topics.  Cannot be substituted for BIOL 121N and BIOL 122N or for BIOL 123N and BIOL 124N.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex biological concepts to non-experts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on biological topics

courseDescription: An introductory, non-sequential course for nonbiology majors focusing on scientific inquiry and the fundamental biological underpinnings of environmental science. The course concentrates on ecology, evolution, the nature of and threats to biodiversity, and conservation solutions. Cannot be substituted for  BIOL 121N or BIOL 123N.  BIOL 110N + BIOL 111N satisfy four credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement.

Laboratory activities and scientific experiments that enhance understanding of environmental science through a hands-on approach that cannot be provided in the lecture classroom setting.  BIOL 110N + BIOL 111N satisfy four credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement.  Cannot be substituted for BIOL 122N or BIOL 124N.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Delegating tasks within a lab group

courseDescription: An introductory, non-sequential course for nonbiology majors focusing on the most serious environmental problems our society is facing today and how these problems can be solved. The course concentrates on the science behind natural resources and resource management, toxicology, environmental policies and ethics, and sustainable living. Cannot be substituted for BIOL 121N or BIOL 123N.  BIOL 112N and BIOL 113N satisfy four credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement.

Laboratory activities and experiments that enhance understanding of the scientific method and environmental sciences through a hands-on approach that cannot be provided in the lecture classroom setting. This course cannot be substituted for BIOL 122N or BIOL 124N. BIOL 112N + BIOL 113N satisfy four credits of the University's Nature of Science general education requirement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using scientific tools and software
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members on experiments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation and drawing conclusions based on results

courseDescription: An introductory lecture course for non-majors focusing on scientific inquiry and the structure and function of the human body with units on diet, nutrition, exercise, infectious disease, and cancer.  Cannot be substituted for BIOL 121N or BIOL 123N.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of human body structure and function
Knowledge of diet and nutrition principles
Understanding of infectious diseases and their impact on the body
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective listening skills in scientific discussions
Clear communication of complex biological concepts to non-scientists
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing scientific data related to human biology
Critical evaluation of research findings in the field of biology
Problem-solving in the context of human health issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to manage time effectively for studying and completing assignments in a scientific course

courseDescription: An introductory lab course for non-majors focusing on scientific inquiry and the structure and function of the human body with units on diet, nutrition, exercise, infectious disease, and cancer. Cannot be substituted for BIOL 122N or BIOL 124N.

An introduction to the process of science, biological molecules, cell biology, metabolism, molecular biology, and Mendelian genetics.  Students required to take BIOL 121N cannot earn credit for BIOL 105N, BIOL 106N, BIOL 110N, BIOL 112N, or BIOL 117N.

A lab course emphasizing the process of science, biological molecules, cell biology, metabolism, molecular biology, and Mendelian genetics.  Students required to take BIOL 122N cannot earn credit for BIOL 111N, BIOL 113N, or BIOL 118N.

A lab course emphasizing the process of science, evolutionary biology, ecology, and the basic biology of viruses, prokaryotes, and eukaryotes.  Students required to take BIOL 124N cannot earn credit for BIOL 111N, BIOL 113N, or BIOL 118N.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a lab environment

courseDescription: This course is available only to students in the Honors College.  An introduction to the process of science, biological molecules, cell biology, metabolism, molecular biology, and Mendelian genetics.  Students required to take BIOL 136N cannot earn credit for BIOL 105N, BIOL 106N, BIOL 110N, BIOL 112N, or BIOL 117N.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex biological concepts to peers

courseDescription: This lab course is available only to students in the Honors College.  This lab course emphasizes the process of science, biological molecules, cell biology, metabolism, molecular biology, and Mendelian genetics.  Students required to take BIOL 137N cannot earn credit for BIOL 111N, BIOL 113N, or BIOL 118N.

This course is available only to students in the Honors College.  An introduction to the process of science, evolutionary biology, ecology, and the basic biology of viruses, prokaryotes, and eukaryotes.  Students required to take BIOL 138N cannot earn credit for BIOL 105N, BIOL 106N, BIOL 110N, BIOL 112N, or BIOL 117N.
Technical and Digital Skills: Basic biology of viruses, prokaryotes, and eukaryotes

courseDescription: This lab course is available only to students in the Honors College.  This lab course emphasizes the process of science, evolutionary biology, ecology, and the basic biology of viruses, prokaryotes, and eukaryotes.  Students required to take BIOL 139N cannot earn credit for BIOL 111N, BIOL 113N, or BIOL 118N.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting scientific findings to a group

courseDescription: A course designed to acquaint the student with the elementary principles of bacteriology and other disease causing microorganisms. Emphasis is placed on microorganisms as etiological agents in disease, on practical methods of disinfection, and on the factors of infection and immunity.

A course designed to acquaint the student with the elementary principles of bacteriology and other disease causing microorganisms. Emphasis is placed on microorganisms as etiological agents in disease, on practical methods of disinfection, and on the factors of infection and immunity.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding factors of infection and immunity
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of etiological agents in diseases

courseDescription: Laboratory topics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of results to peers

courseDescription: Topics in Biology.

Student participation in a supervised, undergraduate research experience for which credit will not apply to the degree.  Experience must be related to the student's major, minor or career area of interest.

courseTitle: Fundamentals of Anatomy and Physiology I
courseDescription: This is the first of a two-part course that investigates the structure and function of the human body. Emphasis is on the basic organization of the body, biochemical composition, cellular structure, function, tissues and organs of the following systems: integumentary, skeletal, muscular, nervous, sensory and endocrine. In lab, students will study the interrelationship between structure and function of the human body using models, histological preparations, and human and feline anatomical specimens. Students with credit for BIOL 240 cannot receive credit for BIOL 250.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing interrelationship between structure and function
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions in lab settings

courseTitle: Fundamentals of Anatomy and Physiology II
courseDescription: The second of a two-part course that investigates the structure and function of the human body.  Emphasis is on the basic organization of the body, biochemical composition, cellular structure, function, tissues and organs of the following systems: cardiovascular, lymphatic, immune, respiratory, urinary, digestive, reproductive and human development. In lab, students will study the interrelationship between structure and function of the human body using models, histological preparations, and human and feline anatomical specimens.  Students with credit for BIOL 241 cannot receive credit for BIOL 251.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing interrelationship between structure and function
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading lab groups in specimen analysis

courseDescription: This course emphasizes the gross anatomical relationships and the molecular, cellular, physiological, and metabolic process of the integument, musculoskeletal, neural, and immune systems.  Students with credit for BIOL 250 cannot receive credit for BIOL 240.

This course emphasizes the physiology and pathophysiology of the cardiac, pulmonary, renal, endocrine, and reproductive systems. Only BIOL 251 (4 credits) may count toward upper-division elective requirements for the Biology major.  Students with credit for BIOL 251 cannot receive credit for BIOL 241.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of cardiac, pulmonary, renal, endocrine, and reproductive systems physiology and pathophysiology
Proficiency in using lab equipment for physiological experiments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex physiological concepts
Collaboration with peers on lab experiments
Presenting research findings in a clear and concise manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing physiological data to draw conclusions
Troubleshooting experimental errors in data collection
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing lab schedules and group tasks
Leading lab experiments and coordinating group efforts

courseDescription: An introduction to the basic concepts of ecology for both biology majors and nonmajors. The concepts are introduced with respect to terrestrial and aquatic environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: GIS mapping for environmental data analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of ecological concepts to diverse audiences

courseDescription: An introduction to the basic concepts of evolution for both biology majors and nonmajors. The concepts are introduced with respect to terrestrial and aquatic environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of evolutionary principles in biology
Identification of evolutionary patterns in terrestrial and aquatic environments
Analysis of genetic variation and adaptation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of evolutionary theories and evidence
Interpretation of evolutionary relationships and phylogenetic trees

courseDescription: A comprehensive course in the structural and functional features of cells, including prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.  The course will also examine biomacromolecules, techniques in cell and molecular biology, and current frontiers in cell biology research.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of research findings to peers and experts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimental design for cell biology studies
Data interpretation and analysis in cell biology research
Troubleshooting experimental issues in the lab

courseDescription: An introduction to the principles of biological inheritance and variation and the molecular basis of gene structure and function.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of gene structure and function at a molecular level
Ability to conduct genetic analysis using software tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of genetic concepts to non-experts
Collaboration with peers on genetic research projects

courseDescription: This course provides a detailed understanding of the four major classes of organic biological molecules as well as inorganic biological molecules (vitamins and trace minerals).  The course focuses on how these biomolecules relate to everyday life for a diversity of organisms.  This course will additionally emphasize current research and topics in the media as they pertain to biomolecules.  This course counts as an elective for BIOL majors; students with premedical, dental or veterinary emphasis should consider if this course will satisfy requirements for medical, dental, or veterinary schools.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding organic and inorganic biological molecules
Interpretation of research data related to biomolecules
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex biological concepts

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide a genuine research experience for undergraduate students at the sophomore/junior level. Students will pursue a novel research question and use modern laboratory techniques to examine this question and test hypotheses.
A review of the phenomena of immune resistance, the cells and tissues involved in immune responses and the consequences of immunization.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identifying cells and tissues involved in immune responses
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex immunological concepts to non-specialists
Collaborating with peers on immunology research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the effectiveness of immunization strategies

courseDescription: The course incorporates the fields of animal physiology, biochemistry, ecology and behavior to provide a comprehensive framework for energy acquisition, processing, and use in animals.  The course content integrates cellular and molecular mechanisms of digestion and absorption, with tissue-specific and whole-animal metabolism, to the environmental influences on food resource availability and the diverse adaptations of animals to specific dietary and energetic constraints.  The course primarily focuses on vertebrate animals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of digestion and absorption mechanisms
Ability to analyze tissue-specific and whole-animal metabolism
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex scientific concepts
Collaboration with peers on research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of environmental influences on food availability
Analyzing adaptations of animals to dietary constraints
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research projects related to animal nutrition
Leading group discussions on course topics

courseDescription: This course in comparative animal nutrition and metabolism explores how diverse animals accomplish the universal task of acquiring food energy from their environments, processing and assimilating these resources, and use food energy in metabolism to support vital functions (e.g. growth, repair, reproduction).
Technical and Digital Skills: Comparative animal nutrition and metabolism analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of animal nutrition data

courseDescription: Human genetics applies the principles of genetics to understanding human disease and evolution. It covers classical genetics, molecular genetics and population genetics, meeting the undergraduate genetics requirement for biology and biochemistry majors.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting genetic data for disease diagnosis
Evaluating evolutionary patterns in human populations

courseDescription: An examination of the invertebrate phyla with emphasis on classification, morphology, phylogeny, and general biology.
A general introduction to the structure, function, ecology, and diversity of plants.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of ecological concepts to non-experts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying plant species based on characteristics
Interpreting ecological data for research purposes

courseDescription: This course is designed to teach the fundamentals of abnormal functions essential to understanding diseases, disease processes, and production of signs and symptoms. Chemical, biological, and biochemical alterations in physiology of all major organ systems will be considered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding chemical, biological, and biochemical alterations in physiology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex concepts in pathophysiology to others
Collaborating with peers on case studies and research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of alterations in organ systems on overall health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on pathophysiology topics
Organizing study groups for exam preparation

courseDescription: An examination of the invertebrate phyla with emphasis on classification, morphology, phylogeny, and general biology. This course will be taught as a full, immersive, field course in the Florida Keys.
Technical and Digital Skills: Morphological identification skills for different phyla
Data collection using digital tools in the field
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers in field research
Communicating effectively with team members during fieldwork
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying unknown invertebrate species based on characteristics
Analyzing field data to draw conclusions about biodiversity
Adapting research methods based on unexpected findings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a field research team in data collection
Managing resources efficiently during field expeditions

courseDescription: This course will emphasize the application of evolutionary and ecological principles such as species geographic range shifts, changes in phenology, acclimation, adaptation, and extinction in response to global environmental changes.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of evolutionary and ecological principles
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers on research projects

courseDescription: This course is designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of the structure and function of the human nervous system, with a major focus on neuroanatomy. The basic principles of cellular neuroscience, neurophysiology, as well as, the sensory and motor pathways will be discussed in detail. Clinically relevant applications will be discussed when relevant. The laboratory component of this course will use cadavers and human tissue to study head and neck structures.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of sensory and motor pathways

courseDescription: An analysis of development in animals.  Lectures will explore experimental approaches to the study of gametogenesis, fertilization, cleavage and morphogenesis.  Laboratories will emphasize the morphological features of the developing vertebrate embryo.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings to peers and professors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing experimental results for developmental patterns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on developmental biology topics

courseDescription: This lecture course is a general survey of the nature and diversity of microorganisms, especially bacteria but including viruses and fungi, the roles and functions of microorganisms and basic microbiological research.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a research team in microbiology projects

courseDescription: Online laboratory course emphasizing basic techniques in microbiology. Students who take BIOL 318 cannot earn credit for BIOL 317.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective online communication with lab partners

courseDescription: A survey of plants used for food, fiber, medicine, dyes, perfumes, oils, and waxes. The role of plants in folklore and religion is included. A student research project with a written paper and presentation is required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation skills for research findings
Collaborative research with peers and experts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of plant properties for specific purposes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on plant uses in different cultures

courseDescription: A survey of the variety, ecology and adaptations of marine organisms. The course is designed to broadly introduce students to life in the oceans and the many special features of marine species that have evolved in the earth's oldest and most extensive ecosystem.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of specialized marine research tools and equipment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of marine research findings
Collaboration with fellow researchers and scientists in the field
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying ecological patterns in marine ecosystems
Developing solutions to conservation challenges in marine environments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing data collection processes in marine biology research projects

courseDescription: This course will emphasize the organisms classified as vertebrates - fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals - in addition to their evolutionary relatives. Detailed discussions of the changes that accompany this diversification of life will include topics in evolution, comparative anatomy, geology, and taxonomy. The lab will be a survey of specimens representing the major groups discussed in lecture.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear communication of complex scientific concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key changes in vertebrate diversification
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on evolutionary topics
Planning and executing research projects in vertebrate zoology

courseDescription: A survey of plants and plant communities of the Mid-Atlantic Coastal Plain.  Skills in plant and mushroom identification, specimen preparation, and research databases are emphasized.  Most classes are field trips.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers in plant identification
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of field data for research purposes

courseDescription: The distribution and characteristics of major plant community types in North America and practices used in the study of biogeography are discussed.

This course is the first semester of a two-semester laboratory and scientific writing course designed to provide a unique undergraduate research experience.  It focuses on the discovery of viruses (also known as bacteriophage or phage) that infect bacteria with an emphasis on laboratory techniques.  Students will collect phage from environmental samples and learn the laboratory techniques required for the isolation, purification and propagation of viruses.  Students will further characterize phage based on microscopy, molecular microbiology techniques, and nucleic acid sequencing.  This course emphasizes independent research and additional time outside of the laboratory will be required for sample collection and analysis.  This course also is designed to complement the MonarchTeach curriculum.

This is the second course of a two semester laboratory and scientific writing sequence that is designed to provide a unique research experience for undergraduate students. The second semester course is a continuation of the research on the phage project that was started in Phage Discovery and Genomics I (BIOL 350). The students will analyze the newly sequenced bacteriophage genome using bioinformatics tools with an emphasis on Genomics. The bioinformatics will be completed using computer software, mathematical modeling and presented in formal scientific laboratory reports and formal presentations. Upon successful completion of the year-long course, some students will be invited to participate in the SEA-PHAGE program coordinated by the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. The course is designed with an emphasis on independent research that could lead to a scientific publication.

Tissue homeostasis requires the birth of new cells, typically derived from stem cells, as well as the removal of cells that are not needed or have become damaged. This course will focus on understanding the mechanisms by which new cells are generated and old or diseased cells are removed. The pathological consequences of failures in one or both of these key processes will be explored as well. Applications of stem cells to regenerative medicine will be considered in detail.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimental design for stem cell research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating research projects with team members
Leading discussions on stem cell biology topics

courseDescription: Student participation for credit in a paid work environment based on the academic relevance of the work experience as determined by the department and the Cooperative Education program, prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.  Unstructured course.  Students must identify a full-time biology faculty member with the expertise to determine if the cooperative education experience is appropriate for a biology curriculum, approve the learning contract, review the submitted assignments (student report and supervisor’s evaluation) and assign a P/F grade.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Team collaboration in a research setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in a research environment
Time management for experiments and data collection
Leading a research team towards common goals

courseDescription: Supervised participation in non-research professional setting.  Requires a minimum of 3 hours per week or equivalent for 1 credit, completion of work report and other documents relevant to the work experience, and supervisor evaluation. Unstructured course. Students must identify a full-time biology faculty member with the expertise to determine if the internship is appropriate for a biology curriculum, approve the learning contract, review the submitted assignments (student report and supervisor’s evaluation) and assign a P/F grade.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Determining internship appropriateness for biology curriculum

courseDescription: A supervised experience in a research, teaching, or a work/field setting and culminating in the preparation of a written document relevant to the practicum experience.  Unstructured course.  Students must identify a full-time biology faculty member with the expertise to determine if the practicum is appropriate for a biology curriculum, approve the learning contract, review the submitted assignments (student report and supervisor’s evaluation) and assign a P/F grade.
A structured specialty course designed to meet the needs of students in biology. Students are expected to perform at the level of other junior level classes.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group projects in biology research

courseDescription: A structured specialty course for students at the junior level. Courses may include lecture and laboratory components.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Delegating tasks in a lab setting

courseDescription: An evolutionary survey of vascular plant families and the principles and methodologies that define them; lab emphasis is placed on recognition and skills of identification. A lab and field intensive hands-on course.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of plant families based on characteristics

courseDescription: A comprehensive survey of the insects, including taxonomy, morphology, physiology, reproductive and developmental biology, and ecology. Research techniques in entomology will be learned through both field and laboratory work. Writing skills will be learned through written summaries, essay exams, laboratory reports and research proposals. This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Writing skills for summaries, reports, and research proposals

courseTitle: Scientific Diving Methods for Marine Research
courseDescription: This lecture/field experience course will train students in the common techniques used by marine scientists who employ scuba for their research. It satisfies the requirements for an American Academy of Underwater Scientist certification and covers other topics such as: use of underwater research equipment and marine resource surveys. A multi-day scuba trip is required.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data analysis of marine research findings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and leading multi-day scuba trips for research purposes

courseDescription: This course integrates the disciplines of microbiology, immunology, and biochemistry with the pathophysiology of infections and the appropriate pharmacology in a problem-based learning setting. Students will learn the fundamental concepts and terminologies of infectious diseases. The material will be case studies in small group tutorials and emphasize independent learning.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in problem-based learning settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of infectious diseases concepts

courseDescription: The application of fundamental biological principles to the preservation of biodiversity, including the role of ecological and evolutionary theory to the preservation of biotas on a regional and global basis.  Lectures will cover modern approaches to conservation biology, including conservation ethics and management issues.  Laboratories will include discussion of case studies, introduction to software applicable to conservation biology, presentations by regional conservation practitioners, and visits to relevant field sites.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementing ecological and evolutionary theory in conservation practices
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing case studies in conservation biology
Evaluating management issues in biodiversity preservation
Implementing conservation ethics in real-world scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading field site visits for conservation research
Coordinating with teams on conservation initiatives

courseDescription: This course offers a capstone experience in scientific writing, faculty-mentored library research, the review and synthesis of material from the primary technical literature, and oral presentation.  Students will develop a deeper understanding of the purposes and types of scientific writing, the structure and interpretation of technical papers, and the oral and written communication skills appropriate to the discipline.  This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Review and synthesis of technical literature
Structure and interpretation of technical papers
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing scientific writing projects

courseDescription: This lecture and laboratory course examines the biology of mammals in depth. Course topics include the evolution of mammalian diversity, mammalian systematics, the behavior and social systems of mammals, mammalian biogeography and ecology, anatomical and physiological specializations in mammals, domestication of mammals, conservation of mammals, and human evolution. The laboratory portion of the course will focus on the various taxonomic groups within the Class: Mammalia through the study of museum material, pictures, video, and primary literature. In addition, students will learn how to identify specific mammal species found in the state of Virginia. Laboratory activities will also include field activities and one required weekend day trip.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of anatomical and physiological adaptations in mammals
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of research findings related to mammalian biology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of mammalian behavior and social systems
Problem-solving in mammalian biogeography and ecology
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and execution of laboratory activities
Leadership in fieldwork expeditions for mammal observation

courseTitle: The Pharmacology and Neurobiology of How Recreational Drugs Work
courseDescription: This course in drug use and abuse is designed to distinguish between drug use and drug abuse as well as provide pharmacological knowledge of how recreational drugs work. Students will acquire knowledge regarding the abuse of prescription drugs, depressants, stimulants, hallucinogens, marijuana and inhalants. This information will be used to analyze pathophysiological conditions that can occur as a result of drug use and abuse.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding pharmacological mechanisms of recreational drugs
Understanding pathophysiological conditions from drug abuse
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying patterns in drug abuse cases
Evaluating the impact of drug abuse on health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on drug abuse topics
Organizing research data on drug use and abuse

courseDescription: This is an introductory course in the theory and practice of zymology (fermentation). Edible and potable products of fermentation (beer, wine, mead, yogurt, cheese) have been known since antiquity and play an important role in today’s society. The science of fermentation touches on many biological disciplines, such as microbiology and biochemistry, and the study of yeasts has provided considerable foundation to the fields of cell biology and molecular biology. In this course, we will cover fundamentals of fermentation and its practical application to production of beer, one of the oldest beverages produced by humans.
Technical and Digital Skills: Biochemistry knowledge for understanding fermentation processes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting findings from fermentation experiments to a group
Communicating fermentation processes effectively to team members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Optimizing fermentation conditions for desired outcomes

courseDescription: Discover the incredible secrets behind what makes our green friends tick.  This course includes a traditional lecture covering the physiological and chemical processes occurring in plants.  A laboratory, greenhouse, and/or field-oriented lab will provide hands-on opportunities to understand plant stress responses, nutrient use, cell metabolism-respiration, photosynthesis, hormones, and processes driving growth patterns.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing solutions for plant stress management

courseDescription: A lecture and laboratory course designed to introduce students to important ecological processes operating in coastal marine environments; this is a writing-intensive course. The course covers synthetic topics as well as the ecology of specific marine habitats. The laboratory is designed to provide students with experience in marine research and the organisms and ecological conditions common in various marine habitats visited by the class.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data collection methods in marine ecology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting ecological research findings to a diverse audience
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively in ecological research projects

courseDescription: A description of common immunological problems seen in the clinic.
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in using bioinformatics tools for immunological data analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients about immunological conditions
Collaboration with other healthcare professionals in treatment plans for immunological disorders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting immunological test results to diagnose conditions
Identifying potential causes of immune system dysfunction in patients
Developing treatment strategies based on immunological findings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing patient records and immunological test data efficiently
Leading immunology research projects to investigate new treatments or diagnostic methods

courseDescription: An exploration of the ecology of inland and coastal wetlands and their plants.  The course emphasizes wetland and aquatic plant identification, field and laboratory methods, and core concepts important to wetland plants and their ecology.  Linkages to wetland delineation and wetland adjacent systems will be made.  Weekly field-based laboratories are expected to local wetlands focusing on hands on opportunities and research methods.
Technical and Digital Skills: Field and laboratory methods for plant research
Hands-on research methods in wetland ecology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting data collected from field studies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading field-based research teams in wetlands
Planning and executing wetland plant research projects

courseDescription: A combined lecture and field study of birds with emphasis on identification, behavior, and field methods.  Extensive field trips, including at least one weekend, are taken.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of birding apps for identification
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of bird behaviors observed
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing bird behaviors in the field
Identifying bird species based on field characteristics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a group during field studies

courseDescription: The molecular organization of eukaryotic cells is presented along with cell evolution, molecular genetics, the internal organization of the cell and the behavior of cells in multicellular organisms. This is a writing intensive course.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating group projects in the lab

courseDescription: An introduction to the basic mechanisms by which different animals function.  How organisms acquire and use energy, regulate their internal environment, circulate and exchange gases and wastes, receive and conduct information about their environment, and move and use muscles will be some of the topics covered.  Emphasis will be on how organisms make changes in these basic mechanisms to deal with different environmental conditions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of energy acquisition and utilization in animals
Understanding of gas exchange and waste regulation in animals
Knowledge of information reception and processing in animals
Understanding of muscle movement in animals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in analyzing animal physiological mechanisms
Ability to identify and adapt to different environmental conditions affecting animals

courseDescription: This course will examine how mutation leads to altered gene products and expression, subverted cell activity, cell immortalization, and tumor formation. Students will explore the differences between benign tumors and malignant tumors as well as the factors involved in malignancy. The course will conclude with the exploration of current cancer therapy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of altered gene products and expression
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of complex scientific concepts
Collaboration with peers on research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of differences between benign and malignant tumors
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on cancer biology topics

courseDescription: The structure and function of cells, tissues and organs at both the light microscopic and ultrastructural levels.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with lab colleagues for data analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting technical issues in histological experiments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating research projects involving histological studies
Training and supervising junior lab members

courseDescription: Examination of bacterium-host interactions with an emphasis on how bacteria cause disease, particularly the means by which the bacterium is able to circumvent host defense mechanisms. This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of bacterial diseases and mechanisms
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings on bacterium-host interactions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data related to bacterial pathogenesis
Identifying mechanisms of bacterial evasion of host defense
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research projects related to microbial pathogenesis
Leading scientific discussions on bacterial diseases

courseDescription: This is a writing intensive course. It is designed to engage students in learning about the different types of plant-animal interactions that occur in a variety of the Earth’s ecosystems. The goal is to understand these interactions and their significance, how they shape communities and ecosystems, and how they maintain biodiversity. A variety of animal taxa and their relationships with plants are investigated, including birds, mammals, bats, fishes, and insects. Varied ecosystems, including wetlands, prairies, tropical and hardwood forests, agricultural lands, tundra, oceans, lakes and more, will be considered.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on research projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing data collection efforts in diverse ecosystems

courseDescription: This highly interdisciplinary science of conserving marine biodiversity will be taught through a review of old and new literature. This will include its history, marine ecology related to conservation biology, threats to marine biodiversity, assessment of extinction risk, conservation challenges of marine habitats and regions, and methods for conserving marine biodiversity.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with interdisciplinary teams for conservation efforts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of marine biodiversity threats
Identification of conservation solutions for marine habitats and regions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for marine conservation initiatives

courseDescription: This lecture course will focus on concepts related to the spread and control of infectious diseases. This course is a writing-intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective scientific writing for research papers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing control strategies based on data analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research teams in studying infectious diseases

courseTitle: One Health: People, Animals and the Environment
courseDescription: A course that examines the interdependence between human health, animal health and environmental health. The One Health approach to the threat of emerging infectious diseases includes understanding the interconnectedness of human and animal pathogens, epidemic zoonoses and corresponding environmental factors, insights into mechanisms of microbial evolution towards pathogenicity, new technologies and approaches towards disease surveillance, and political and bureaucratic strategies. This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of human, animal, and environmental health interdependencies
Knowledge of human and animal pathogens
Knowledge of microbial evolution towards pathogenicity
Familiarity with disease surveillance technologies and approaches
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective writing skills for communicating complex health concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of interconnected health factors
Analyzing mechanisms of microbial evolution towards pathogenicity
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategizing political and bureaucratic approaches to health challenges

courseDescription: The major objective of this hands-on course is to prepare students to independently perform basic laboratory techniques, assays, and experiments commonly used in entry-level immunology laboratory positions. The course will cover theory, sample and reagent preparation, instrumentation, data analysis and interpretation, and applications in immunology. Several topics covered in-class include ELISAs, mammalian cell culture, and flow cytometry; however, additional topics (such as confocal microscopy) will be covered using virtual technologies. This course is ideal for students who intend to pursue careers at the laboratory bench.

Animal behavior with special attention to its evolution and ecological significance. Field and laboratory activities will emphasize the observational and experimental techniques used to study behavior.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing data collection efforts in the field

courseDescription: An intensive study abroad field course offered during the summer at a foreign  marine laboratory where students will be engaged in lectures and field studies of coastal marine environments.  Check with the Director of the Marine Biology Concentration Program for details.
Technical and Digital Skills: Field sampling techniques in marine biology
Data collection methods in marine environments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of research findings to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data collected in marine field studies
Identifying patterns in marine ecosystem data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing data collection schedules in marine environments

courseDescription: The goal of this course is to introduce and evaluate both classical and emerging paradigms in community ecology.  This will be achieved by examining those processes (biotic and abiotic) that structure ecological communities and by exposing students to quantitative and theoretical aspects of these paradigms.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing biotic and abiotic factors in ecological communities

courseDescription: The principles of fluid and solid mechanics will be applied to a variety of plant and animal systems to understand how organisms deal with the immediate physical world and its accompanying constraints.  A diverse range of topics will be covered, including aerial flight in insects, wind resistance in trees, jet propulsion in squid, flow within blood vessels, forces on intertidal organisms, viscoelasticity in biological materials, and energy storage during terrestrial movement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Biomechanical analysis of plant and animal systems

courseDescription: This course uses conceptual and mathematical models to understand how populations grow and persist in space and time. Both plants and animals are discussed.

This course introduces the student to microorganisms with particular emphasis placed on their role in health, wellness and disease.  Economic, social and cultural issues related to utilization, control, and research of the bacteria and viruses are also considered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of bacterial and viral cultures for research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of research findings related to health impact of microorganisms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of microbial research data
Identification of microorganism impacts on health and disease
Problem-solving in microbial control and utilization scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in coordinating research efforts on microbial impact on human health

courseDescription: This course explores theoretical concepts in plant ecology through review of classical and cutting-edge literature and practice with field-based experimental design and statistical methods. This course emphasizes the structure, development, and processes that drive patterns in plant communities and the ecological communities they support. Weekly field-based laboratories involve hands-on experience and opportunities to explore field methods in ecological research.

The application of computer science to biology has led to major breakthroughs in the ability to read and understand the code written in genomes. This course will give students the skills to participate in the computational revolution in biology. The course will give students hands-on experience in writing simple yet powerful computer programs in the Python programming language and making beautiful data visualizations in the R programming language. Students will also learn how to combine existing pieces of bioinformatics software for their own workflows.

The application of computer science to biology has led to major breakthroughs in the ability to read and understand the code written in genomes. This course will give students the skills to participate in the computational revolution in biology. The course will build on the knowledge of writing programs. Students will learn about some key techniques “under the hood” of software that have been critical to the genomics revolution. Topics will include: graph algorithms, evolutionary trees, probability models for DNA and protein sequences, and an introduction to deep learning in biology.
Technical and Digital Skills: Probability models for DNA and protein sequences

courseDescription: This course will explore the biology of organisms by using molecular (nucleic acid and/or protein) techniques and data. It covers a wide variety of subdisciplines within Biology, including genetics, physiology, ecology, and evolution. This course will explore basic theory in population genetics, ecology, and evolution and cover DNA, RNA, and Protein techniques and their application to biological research.

courseTitle: Research in Pathogen Biology I: Laboratory Investigation
courseDescription: This is the first course of a two-semester laboratory and analysis sequence that is designed to provide a genuine research experience for undergraduate students. Students will design a novel research question in pathogen biology, then use modern laboratory techniques such as polymerase chain reaction and next-generation DNA sequencing to examine this question and test hypotheses. Data generated in this course will be analyzed in the second course in the series, BIOL 455. Data and analyses generated during these courses may be used for publication in scientific journals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing research questions in pathogen biology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on research projects

courseTitle: Research in Pathogen Biology II: Analysis
courseDescription: This is the second course of a two-semester laboratory and analysis sequence that is designed to provide a genuine research experience for undergraduate students. In this semester, students will analyze data generated during the previous semester in BIOL 454. Modern methods of data analysis will be used, including statistical and bioinformatics techniques. Data and analyses generated during these courses may be used for publication in scientific journals.

A basic course covering the history of virology, viral taxonomy, genetics, and the molecular biology and host responses to the major mammalian virus groups.  Examples of recent impacts of viruses on human health such as influenza pandemics will also be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Molecular biology techniques for virus study
Impacts of viruses on human health research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on virus-related projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on virology topics

courseDescription: Review of the structure, synthesis and properties of key nano-materials and their impact on living systems.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings on nano-materials impact on living systems
Collaborating with interdisciplinary teams on nanoscience projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the effects of nano-materials on living systems
Identifying potential challenges in nanotechnology applications
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time and resources effectively in nanotechnology research

courseDescription: Students will dissect a human cadaver fully and learn all of the major structures. The course will be divided into three sections: back and limbs, TAP (thorax, abdomen and pelvis), and head and neck. Instructor demonstrations include brain removal and dissection.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking initiative in learning specific structures
Assisting peers in understanding complex dissection procedures

courseDescription: This course will emphasize the fundamental concepts of microbial genetics including the study of gene structure, gene regulation, operons, DNA replication, RNA biology, protein synthesis, plasmid biology, mobile genetic elements, and recombinant DNA technology.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills in recombinant DNA technology

courseTitle: Cell Signaling in Host Pathogen Interactions
courseDescription: This course will emphasize cell dynamics including host and pathogen induced cellular signaling, the regulation of actin cytoskeleton rearrangement, and the modulation of host transcription and translation by different pathogens.
Technical and Digital Skills: Host transcription and translation modulation knowledge
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of cell signaling mechanisms
Problem-solving in cellular response to pathogens

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of how microbes are manipulated to solve practical problems through biotechnology.  Topics include basic concepts in microbial technology, industrial microbiology, microbes in drug development, food microbiology, microbial interactions, gut microbiota, and metagenomics.

courseTitle: Introduction to Mitigation and Adaptation Studies
courseDescription: Students will be introduced to the science underpinning mitigation of human-induced changes in the Earth system, including but not limited to climate change and sea level rise, and adaptation to the impacts of these changes. The course will cover the environmental hazards and the opportunities and limitations for conservation, mitigation and adaptation. This is a writing intensive course. Cross listed with IDS 466W and OEAS 466W.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective writing skills for scientific reports
Presenting mitigation and adaptation strategies to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data on human-induced changes in Earth system
Identifying limitations and opportunities for mitigation and adaptation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating mitigation and adaptation efforts across different sectors

courseDescription: In this class, students will discover what makes a leader for sustainability. They will consider a range of global and local crises from a leadership point of view in the context of sustainability science, which addresses the development of communities in a rapidly changing social, economic, and environmental system-of-systems environment. The course will be based on taking a problem-motivated and solution-focused approach to the challenges considered. The course includes a service learning project focusing on a leadership experience in solving a real-world environmental problem.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective team collaboration in sustainability projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing innovative solutions for sustainability issues

courseTitle: Research Methods in Mathematics and Science
courseDescription: Emphasizes the tools and techniques used to solve scientific problems. Topics include use and design of experiments, use of statistics to interpret experimental results, mathematical modeling of scientific phenomena, and oral and written presentation of scientific results. Students will perform four independent inquiries, combining skills from mathematics and science to solve research problems. Required for Biology teaching licensure track; not available as upper-division elective in content area.  This is a writing intensive course.

Despite advancements in the development of antimicrobials and vaccines and in securing clear water and food supplies, modern civilizations are not immune to epidemic diseases. This course will provide insight into the role of different technologies in the struggle to attain disease control and eradication and explore the challenge of forecasting emerging plagues, describing the nature and evolution of diseases and conveying their significance in shaping Western culture and civilization, their impact, their consequences, their costs, and the lessons learned.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the nature and evolution of diseases
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conveying the significance of diseases in shaping Western culture and civilization
Communicating the impact and consequences of diseases
Sharing lessons learned from disease control and eradication efforts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the costs of disease control and eradication efforts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating disease control and eradication strategies
Leading efforts to combat emerging plagues

courseDescription: Course will explore the biology, diversity and major life history patterns of a suite of marine megafauna, including sea turtles, marine mammals, seabirds and sharks. Students will determine the major drivers behind large-scale declines of many marine megafauna species and be challenged to understand and attempt to solve conservation and management issues. This is a writing intensive course, with a focus on the content and mechanics of scientific writing. Pre- or
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying drivers of marine megafauna declines
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading teams in marine ecology research

courseDescription: This course will focus on understanding brain structure as well as the morphology and function of the central nervous system in general. Fundamental processes such as neuron morphogenesis, guidance, polarity, migration, and growth cone motility will be emphasized. The cellular and molecular basis of neurological disorders also will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Cellular and molecular basis of neurological disorders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of neuron guidance and polarity
Identification of cellular and molecular mechanisms in neurological disorders

courseDescription: Introduction to the immune system, tumor antigens, immunosuppressive cells and molecules, and cancer immunotherapy treatment approaches.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with immunosuppressive cells and molecules
Understanding of cancer immunotherapy treatment approaches
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effectively communicating complex scientific concepts to non-experts
Collaborating with multidisciplinary teams in research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of tumor antigen interactions with the immune system
Analyzing the effectiveness of different cancer immunotherapy approaches
Problem-solving in designing personalized immunotherapy strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research projects in cancer immunotherapy
Organizing and coordinating clinical trials for immunotherapy treatments

courseDescription: Study of the interactions between microorganisms, particularly bacteria, and their environment.  Emphasis is placed on nutrient cycling and the influence of microbes on global mineral dynamics.  The effects of physical and chemical factors on the distribution and activity of microbes in their environments and the applications (biotechnology) of these interactions are studied.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of biotechnology in microbial interactions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of research findings related to microbial ecology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effects of physical and chemical factors on microbial distribution and activity
Critical evaluation of microbial interactions in different environments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing experiments related to microbial ecology
Leading research projects in microbial ecology

courseDescription: A laboratory for measurement of microbial numbers and activity in natural environments.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a laboratory setting

courseDescription: This is a writing intensive course that provides a comprehensive survey of the insects used in legal investigations and medically important insects. Topics covered include the taxonomy, morphology, physiology, reproductive and developmental biology, and ecology of these insects along with the diseases they may vector. Research techniques in forensic and medical entomology will be learned through both field and laboratory activities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Field and laboratory activities in entomology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing reproductive and developmental biology data
Applying ecological concepts to entomological research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research teams in entomology studies

courseDescription: The course will emphasize the principles of parasitism, including biology, physiology, genetics, morphology, and phylogeny of the major parasitic groups with a specific focus on the significant parasites of humans and animals of veterinary importance.  The general biology of parasites including their life cycles, diagnosis, and treatment will be included as well.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding principles of parasitism in biology
Knowledge of physiology, genetics, morphology, and phylogeny of major parasitic groups
Diagnosis and treatment of parasites in humans and animals
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of parasitic concepts to diverse audiences
Collaboration with peers on parasite research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of parasite biology information
Identification of significant parasites in veterinary practice
Analysis of parasite life cycles for diagnosis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing data on parasites for research purposes

courseDescription: Student performs mentored research in biological science. Student and faculty mentor must meet on a regular basis. The course is intended to be taken as a series with BIOL 488W.  Available for pass/fail grading only.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating research tasks with team members

courseDescription: Independent study and scheduled meetings with faculty advisor.  Supervised independent study in an area of individual interest in biology.  The work in this course results in the production of a thesis.  This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers in research projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on research topics

courseDescription: All major physiological systems will be examined with an emphasis on normal physiology. Some clinical applications will be discussed.

Ecological entrepreneurs consider the impact of products on the environment and are mindful of natural resources, sustainability, and social equity. In this novel class students will test their skill at biologically-inspired entrepreneurship after learning about biomimicry, sustainability, and other relevant concepts.
A structured specialty course for students at the senior level. Courses may include lecture and laboratory components.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective scientific communication through presentations and reports
Ability to explain complex biological concepts to non-experts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for balancing lectures and labs

courseDescription: The student performs laboratory and/or field research under the supervision of a Department of Biological Sciences faculty  member.  The student must devote a minimum of 3 hours per week for the equivalent of 1 credit.  The student must maintain lab/field notes, must submit a written report, may be required to give an oral presentation, and must be evaluated by the faculty supervisor.  If 3 credits are taken, then BIOL 497 counts as an upper-level biology elective course with a laboratory or field component.

This unstructured course is based on a supervised project, without a laboratory or field component, that is selected to suit the needs of the individual student.  The completion of a formal scientific paper documented with the appropriate primary technical literature is required.  An oral presentation also may be required.  Contact the Chief Departmental Advisor for details.

An evolutionary survey of vascular plant families and the principles and methodologies that define them; lab emphasis is placed on recognition and skills of identification. A lab and field intensive hands-on course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear communication of findings and observations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of plant families based on principles and methodologies

courseDescription: A comprehensive survey of the insects, including taxonomy, morphology, physiology, reproductive and developmental biology, and ecology.  Research techniques in entomology will be learned through both field and laboratory work.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration in fieldwork and lab settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation from field and lab experiments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing field research projects

courseTitle: Scientific Diving Methods for Marine Research
courseDescription: This lecture/field experience course will train students in the common techniques used by marine scientists who employ scuba for their research. It satisfies the requirements for an American Academy of Underwater Scientist certification and covers other topics such as: use of underwater research equipment and marine resource surveys. A multi-day scuba trip is required.

This course integrates the disciplines of microbiology, immunology, and biochemistry with the pathophysiology of infections and the appropriate pharmacology in a problem-based learning setting. Students will learn the fundamental concepts and terminologies of infectious diseases. The material will be case studies in small group tutorials and emphasize independent learning.

The application of fundamental biological principles to the preservation of biodiversity, including the role of ecological and evolutionary theory to the preservation of biotas on a regional and global basis.  Lectures will cover modern approaches to conservation biology, including conservation ethics and management issues.  Laboratories will include discussion of case studies, introduction to software applicable to conservation biology, presentations by regional conservation practitioners, and visits to relevant field sites.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis software for biodiversity preservation
GIS mapping tools for conservation projects
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with regional conservation practitioners
Collaboration with field experts on conservation projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing ecological and evolutionary theories for biodiversity preservation
Problem-solving in conservation ethics and management
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading field visits to relevant sites
Coordinating group discussions on conservation issues

courseTitle: The Pharmacology and Neurobiology of How Recreational Drugs Work
courseDescription: This course in drug use and abuse is designed to distinguish between drug use and drug abuse as well as provide pharmacological knowledge of how recreational drugs work. Students will acquire knowledge regarding the abuse of prescription drugs, depressants, stimulants, hallucinogens, marijuana and inhalants. This information will be used to analyze pathophysiological conditions that can occur as a result of drug use and abuse.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing pathophysiological conditions from drug use
Knowledge of depressants, stimulants, hallucinogens, marijuana, and inhalants
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting information on drug use and abuse
Collaborating on case studies related to drug abuse
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying the impact of drug abuse on the body
Analyzing the mechanisms of action of recreational drugs
Evaluating the risks and benefits of various drug types
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on drug-related topics
Organizing presentations on the pharmacology of recreational drugs

courseDescription: This is a general introductory course in pharmacology dealing with chemistry, general properties and pharmacological effects on various physiological systems, therapeutic usefulness and toxicities of drugs.  The course is designed to prepare upper-level undergraduate and graduate students for more advanced courses in pharmacology.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers in advanced courses
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of therapeutic usefulness of drugs
Identifying and managing toxicities of drugs

courseDescription: This is an introductory course in the theory and practice of zymology (fermentation). Edible and potable products of fermentation (beer, wine, mead, yogurt, cheese) have been known since antiquity and play an important role in today’s society. The science of fermentation touches on many biological disciplines, such as microbiology and biochemistry, and the study of yeasts has provided considerable foundation to the fields of cell biology and molecular biology. In this course, we will cover fundamentals of fermentation and its practical application to production of beer, one of the oldest beverages produced by humans.

Discover the incredible secrets behind what makes our green friends tick. This course includes a traditional lecture covering the physiological and chemical processes occurring in plants. A laboratory, greenhouse, and/or field-oriented lab will provide hands-on opportunities to understand plant stress responses, nutrient use, cell metabolism-respiration, photosynthesis, hormones, and processes driving growth patterns.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group experiments in the greenhouse/field

courseDescription: A lecture and laboratory course designed to introduce students to important ecological processes operating in coastal marine environments.  The course covers synthetic topics as well as the ecology of specific marine habitats.  The laboratory is designed to provide students with experience in marine research and the organisms and ecological conditions common in various marine habitats visited by the class.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing research hypotheses in marine ecology
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing data collected in marine habitats

courseDescription: A description of common immunological problems seen in the clinic.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex immunological concepts to patients
Collaboration with healthcare professionals for patient care
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of immune system abnormalities in patient cases

courseDescription: An exploration of the ecology of inland and coastal wetlands and their plants. This course emphasizes wetland and aquatic plant identification, field and laboratory methods, and core concepts important to wetland plants and their ecology. Linkages to wetland delineation and wetland adjacent systems will be made. Weekly field-based laboratories are expected to local wetlands focusing on hands on opportunities and research methods.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of wetland plant ecology

courseDescription: The biology of marine and freshwater fishes including morphology, physiology, evolution, distribution, ecology, and reproduction.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating on field studies with other researchers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying fish species based on characteristics
Analyzing distribution patterns of fish populations
Interpreting ecological data to draw conclusions

courseDescription: A combined lecture and field study of birds with emphasis on identification, behavior, and field methods.  Extensive field trips, including at least one weekend, are taken.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of birding apps for identification
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Sharing bird observations with the group
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing bird calls and songs for identification
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading birdwatching groups during field trips
Organizing logistics for weekend field trips
Coordinating group activities during field studies

courseDescription: The molecular organization of eukaryotic cells is presented along with cell evolution, molecular genetics, the internal organization of the cell and the behavior of cells in multicellular organisms.

An introduction to the basic mechanisms by which different animals function.  How organisms acquire and use energy, regulate their internal environment, circulate and exchange gases and wastes, receive and conduct information about their environment, and move and use muscles will be some of the topics covered.  Emphasis will be on how organisms make changes in these basic mechanisms to deal with different environmental conditions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of energy acquisition and utilization mechanisms in animals
Knowledge of internal environment regulation in different animal species
Understanding of gas exchange and waste management in animals
Knowledge of information reception and processing in various animal species
Understanding of muscle movement and usage in animals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of animal physiological mechanisms
Identification of adaptations in animals to different environmental conditions
Problem-solving in understanding animal responses to environmental changes

courseDescription: This course will examine how mutation leads to altered gene products and expression, subverted cell activity, cell immortalization, and tumor formation. Students will explore the differences between benign tumors and malignant tumors as well as the factors involved in malignancy. The course will conclude with the exploration of current cancer therapy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of gene mutations and altered gene products
Knowledge of cell immortalization and tumor formation
Differentiation between benign and malignant tumors
Understanding of factors contributing to malignancy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing cell activity and tumor characteristics

courseDescription: The structure and function of cells, tissues and organs at both the light microscopic and ultrastructural levels.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with lab partners for sample analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying cellular structures under the microscope
Analyzing tissue function based on structure

courseDescription: Examination of bacterium-host interactions with an emphasis on how bacteria cause disease, particularly the means by which the bacterium is able to circumvent host defense mechanisms
Technical and Digital Skills: Identification of host defense evasion strategies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of research findings related to microbial pathogenesis
Collaboration with peers on research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data on bacterial disease causation
Identifying solutions to combat bacterial evasion tactics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research projects on microbial pathogenesis
Organizing and coordinating experiments to study bacterium-host interactions

Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Threat assessment and mitigation strategies for marine biodiversity

Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear communication of complex concepts to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation for infectious disease trends
Critical evaluation of research methodologies in infectious disease studies
