In this semester, students will analyze data generated during the previous semester in BIOL 554. Modern methods of data analysis will be used, including statistical and bioinformatics techniques. Data and analyses generated during these courses may be used for publication in scientific journals.

A basic course covering the history of virology, viral taxonomy, genetics, and the molecular biology and host responses to the major mammalian virus groups.  Examples of recent impacts of viruses on human health such as influenza pandemics will also be covered.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of viral impacts on human health

courseDescription: Review of the structure, synthesis and properties of key nano-materials and their impact on living systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Impact of nano-materials on living systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex nano-science concepts to non-experts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key properties affecting living systems
Evaluating potential applications of nano-materials in medicine
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research teams in nano-material studies
Coordinating experimental work on nano-material synthesis
Managing project timelines for nano-science research

courseDescription: Students will dissect a human cadaver fully and learn all of the major structures. The course will divided into three sections: backs and limbs, TAP (thorax, abdomen and pelvis), and head and neck. Instructor demonstrations include brain removal and dissection.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with instructors and peers

courseDescription: This course emphasizes the fundamental concepts of microbial genetics including the study of gene structure, gene regulation, operons, DNA replication, RNA biology, protein synthesis, plasmid biology, mobile genetic elements, and recombinant DNA technology.

courseTitle: Cell Signaling in Host Pathogen Interactions
courseDescription: This course will emphasize cell dynamics including host and pathogen induced cellular signaling, the regulation of actin cytoskeleton rearrangement, and the modulation of host transcription and translation by different pathogens.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of cell signaling data

courseTitle: Biomedical Applications of Low Temperature Plasmas
courseDescription: This course is cross listed between ECE and Biology. It is intended for senior undergraduate students and first year graduate students. The course contents are multidisciplinary, combining materials from engineering and the biological sciences. The course covers an introduction to the fundamentals of non-equilibrium plasmas, low temperature plasma sources, and cell biology. This is followed by a detailed discussion of the interaction of low temperature plasma with biological cells, both prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Potential applications in medicine such as wound healing, blood coagulation, sterilization, and the killing of various types of cancer cells will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of low temperature plasma sources
Interaction of low temperature plasma with biological cells
Applications in medicine like wound healing and blood coagulation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex scientific concepts
Collaboration between engineering and biological sciences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of low temperature plasma effects on different cell types
Identifying potential applications in medicine based on plasma-cell interactions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on integrating engineering and biological sciences

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of how microbes are manipulated to solve practical problems through biotechnology. Topics to be covered include basic concepts in microbial technology, industrial microbiology, microbes in drug development, food microbiology, microbial interactions, gut microbiota, and metagenomics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative research with team members in the field of biotechnology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills in metagenomics data interpretation

courseDescription: Students will be introduced to the science underpinning mitigation of human-induced changes in the Earth system, including but not limited to climate change and sea level rise, and adaptation to the impacts of these changes. The course will cover the environmental hazards and the opportunities and limitations for conservation, mitigation and adaptation. Cross listed with OEAS 566.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of mitigation and adaptation plans
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of Earth system changes
Problem-solving for limitations in mitigation and adaptation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and coordinating mitigation and adaptation plans

courseDescription: In this class, students will discover what makes a leader for sustainability. They will consider a range of global and local crises from a leadership point of view in the context of sustainability science, which addresses the development of communities in a rapidly changing social, economic, and environmental system-of-systems environment. The course will be based on taking a problem-motivated and solution-focused approach to the challenges considered. The course includes a service learning project focusing on a leadership experience in solving a real-world environmental problem.

Despite advancements in the development of antimicrobials and vaccines and in securing clear water and food supplies, modern civilizations are not immune to epidemic diseases. This course will provide insight into the role of different technologies in the struggle to attain disease control and eradication and explore the challenge of forecasting emerging plagues, describing the nature and evolution of diseases and conveying their significance in shaping Western culture and civilization, their impact, their consequences, their costs, and the lessons learned.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of forecasting methods for epidemics
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective conveying of the significance of diseases in shaping culture and civilization
Ability to communicate the impact and consequences of diseases
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of the nature and evolution of diseases
Analyzing the costs associated with disease control and eradication
Drawing lessons from past disease outbreaks
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to lead efforts in disease control and eradication
Organizing resources for combating emerging plagues

courseDescription: Course will explore the biology, diversity and major life history patterns of a suite of marine megafauna, including sea turtles, marine mammals, seabirds and sharks. Students will determine the major drivers behind large-scale declines of many marine megafauna species and be challenged to understand and attempt to solve conservation and management issues.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with stakeholders in conservation efforts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying drivers of decline in marine megafauna populations
Developing conservation solutions based on data analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing community outreach programs for marine conservation

courseDescription: This course will focus on understanding brain structure as well as the morphology and function of the central nervous system in general. Fundamental processes such as neuron morphogenesis, guidance, polarity, migration, and growth cone motility will be emphasized. The cellular and molecular basis of neurological disorders also will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Central nervous system morphology and function
Cellular and molecular basis of neurological disorders

courseDescription: Introduction to the immune system, tumor antigens, immunosuppressive cells and molecules, and cancer immunotherapy treatment approaches.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with immunosuppressive cells and molecules
Awareness of cancer immunotherapy treatment approaches
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex immunological concepts
Collaboration with healthcare professionals for patient care
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of tumor antigens for immunotherapy targeting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on cancer immunology research
Organizing collaborative efforts for immunotherapy clinical trials

courseDescription: Study of the interactions between microorganisms, particularly bacteria, and their environment.  Emphasis is placed on nutrient cycling and the influence of microbes on global mineral dynamics.  The effects of physical and chemical factors on distribution and activity of microbes in their environments and applications of these interactions are studied (biotechnology).
A laboratory for measurement of microbial numbers and activity in natural environments.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation for microbial numbers and activity

courseDescription: This course provides a comprehensive survey of the insects used in legal investigations and medically important insects. Topics covered include the taxonomy, morphology, physiology, reproductive and developmental biology, and ecology of these insects along with the diseases they may vector. Research techniques in forensic and medical entomology will be learned through both field and laboratory activities.

The course will emphasize the principles of parasitism, including biology, physiology, genetics, morphology, and phylogeny of the major parasitic groups with a specific focus on the significant parasites of humans and animals of veterinary importance.  The general biology of parasites including their life cycles, diagnosis, and treatment will be included as well.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of biology, physiology, genetics, morphology, and phylogeny of parasitic groups
Diagnosis and treatment methods for parasites
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of parasitic concepts to diverse audiences
Collaboration with peers on parasite research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of parasite biology and characteristics
Identification of key parasites based on specific criteria
Analyzing parasite life cycles for diagnosis and treatment strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing parasite data and information

courseDescription: All major physiological systems with emphasis on normal physiology.  Some clinical applications made but not stressed.
A structured specialty course for students at the senior level. Courses may include lecture and laboratory components.

Supervised (non-lab/field) project selected to suit the needs of the individual student. Requires completion of formal scientific paper documented with appropriate primary technical literature (see GPD for details). Unstructured course.
Reading and discussion course designed to explore a field of specific interest.

This course will focus on the mechanisms of action of microbial toxins, including those affecting the host's nervous system, immune function, metabolism, protein synthesis, and homeostasis.  The structure and function of representatives of several toxin types will be analyzed for their potential applications to biotechnology and medicine.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding mechanisms of action of microbial toxins
Identifying toxin effects on host systems
Evaluating potential applications in biotechnology and medicine
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of toxin interactions with host systems
Identifying toxin targets for therapeutic interventions
Applying knowledge to develop toxin-based treatments

courseDescription: Supervised projects and practica selected to meet the specific objectives of the student.
With approval of Advisory Committee.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with team members on experiments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Prioritizing tasks in a fast-paced environment

courseDescription: A lab-intensive course emphasizing current methods in molecular biology.
A specially designed course concerning specific topics in the biological, environmental or allied health fields.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Delegating tasks in a lab setting
Time management for experiments and data analysis

courseDescription: This course is selected with the recommendation of the faculty advisor.

This physiology course will focus solely on cardiovascular physiology.  Lectures will focus on basic and advance cardiovascular principles.  The laboratory will focus on the use of current cardiovascular research.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing laboratory equipment for cardiovascular experiments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on laboratory experiments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting experimental issues in the lab
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group projects in cardiovascular research

courseDescription: This hands-on training course emphasizes the use of general computing tools to work more effectively in the biological sciences. It integrates a broad range of powerful and flexible tools that are applicable to ecologists, molecular biologists, physiologists, and anyone who has struggled analyzing large or complex data sets. Text file manipulation with regular expressions, basic shell scripting, programming in Python and R, interaction with remote devices, and basic graphical concepts will be reviewed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Text file manipulation with regular expressions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing large or complex data sets

courseDescription: Review and discussion of current papers in the areas of biomedical sciences.  Student presentation, discussions and readings in this field required.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for readings and presentations

courseDescription: This course is designed to teach students the various steps involved in analyzing next-generation sequencing data for gene expression profiling and polymorphism identification and analyses. The class will follow a workshop setting with a combination of lectures, paper discussions, and instructor and student led programming sessions.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of gene expression data
Identifying patterns and trends in data

courseDescription: This course integrates the physiological and biochemical function of wild animals with population-scale and community-scale ecological patterns. Both organismal mechanisms and comprehensive theories will be included. The course primarily draws on peer-reviewed literature and includes lecture and discussion.
Technical and Digital Skills: Physiological and biochemical understanding of wild animals
Interpreting peer-reviewed literature on animal physiology
Applying comprehensive theories to ecological patterns
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings on animal ecophysiology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing organismal mechanisms in wild animals
Integrating physiological and ecological data for population-scale patterns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on animal ecophysiology topics

courseDescription: Investigate microbiology from historical perspectives to modern molecular microbiology; ecological and biomedical components; bacteria and viruses. Discussions will include how to design experiments and evaluate results.

Ecological principles at ecosystem level of biological organization.  Discussion of energy flow, nutrient cycling, ecosystem stability and ecosystem modeling.  Laboratory involves field trips and methods of measuring ecosystem parameters.
Technical and Digital Skills: Field work techniques for measuring ecosystem parameters
Data analysis for energy flow and nutrient cycling
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration during field trips and lab work
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting data related to energy flow and nutrient cycling
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing field trips and lab activities
Leading group discussions on ecosystem ecology

courseDescription: A graduate seminar course in the ecological sciences.  The format of the course depends on the faculty running the seminar, but most seminars involve student-led discussions on current research articles.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data visualization using R or Python
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Formulating research questions based on current literature
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for preparation and participation

courseDescription: This course will cover selected current topics in cell biology that reflect recent advances in the field. Major topics include membranes and transport, signal transduction, cell adhesion and motility, cell cycle, apoptosis, and specialized cell functions. Students will read current research papers that describe the latest innovations in microscopic and molecular analysis of cellular function. This course is built on previous coursework in cell biology by reinforcing key fundamental concepts and performing a more in-depth examination of cellular mechanisms.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective research paper reading and analysis
Collaboration on research projects with peers
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on research papers
Organizing research project timelines and tasks

courseDescription: Lectures will cover theory and concepts of specimen preparation and operation of various microscopes used in the biological sciences.  The laboratory experience will include specimen preparation to viewing.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying optimal viewing conditions for different specimens

courseDescription: Three laboratory rotations (6 credits) are required by the curriculum.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordination of research tasks with team members

Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis software (e.g., GraphPad Prism, ImageJ)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with team members on projects
Communicating results effectively to peers and supervisors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing hypotheses based on experimental outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Supervising and training new lab members
Prioritizing tasks effectively to meet deadlines

courseDescription: The biochemical integration of hormones and related agents on vertebrate physiology with emphasis on human endocrinology. Recent literature will be stressed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers in discussing recent literature
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Integration of biochemical data to understand hormone effects on physiology
Critical evaluation of recent literature in endocrinology
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing research projects in the field of endocrinology

courseDescription: A systematic survey of fishes emphasizing life history, anatomy, identification and classification.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of research findings related to fish species
Collaboration with fellow researchers in the field of ichthyology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying patterns in fish life history data
Critical evaluation of fish anatomy information for classification purposes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading field surveys for fish population studies
Organizing data collected from fish surveys for further analysis

courseDescription: This course will provide a comprehensive discussion of the physiological and chemical properties of nerve and muscle cells.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding nerve and muscle cell physiology
Chemical properties of nerve and muscle cells analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in nerve and muscle cell function analysis

courseDescription: Discussion on current studies into new and reemerging infectious diseases with an examination of the infectious agent and factors involved in disease emergence, prevention and elimination.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Public health education on infectious diseases
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data analysis for infectious disease trends
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing effective strategies for disease control
Leading teams in infectious disease research

courseDescription: Principles of systematic biology and discussion of speciation theory, with emphasis on generation, analysis, and interpretation of taxonomic data and application of these data to a better understanding of classification and speciation processes.  Modern theories of evolutionary biology and phylogenetics will be stressed.  A research paper is required.
This course is designed to introduce students to geographic information systems through examples and applications in the life sciences.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Clear communication of GIS findings to non-technical audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving using GIS tools and techniques
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for GIS applications in life sciences

courseDescription: One Health is a concept that stresses the interconnectedness of human, animal, and environmental/ecosystem health and seeks an integrative approach to human and animal health issues. The concept provides a framework for examining complex health issues such as vector-borne and emerging infectious diseases, antimicrobial resistance, and food safety and security. In our globalized world, new approaches to preventing, treating, and controlling diseases are urgently needed as emerging diseases are increasing in frequency due to interconnected ecosystems and the close connections between humans and animals.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis in R or Python
GIS mapping for health data analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Statistical analysis for public health data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for One Health initiatives

courseDescription: This course will explore a broad range of concepts important to the field of vaccinology. Primary literature will be used to discuss vaccine development topics such as vaccine design and production, delivery methods, adjuvants, One Health, and zoonotic vaccines. HIV, TB, malaria, influenza, and parasite vaccines will be included.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data analysis for vaccine efficacy assessment

courseDescription: Current concepts in cellular and molecular immunology and host defense based on critical review of the primary literature.
Required of all graduate students admitted to Biology programs. The course will introduce students to the responsible conduct of science and scientific research.

courseTitle: Functional Genomics and Proteomics in Animal Models
courseDescription: The purpose of this course is to show how animal models of human diseases can be created and analyzed using genomic and proteomic technologies. The course will overview high throughput methods of generating disease models in mice and describe ongoing efforts in this field. Attempts to identify molecular mechanisms of the disease will be presented with particular emphasis on drug target discovery.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining complex scientific concepts to non-experts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing large datasets for patterns and correlations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating interdisciplinary teams for research projects
Prioritizing tasks in a research setting

courseDescription: Emphasis on historical biogeography, utilizing both dispersal and vicariance models for explanations of the geographic distribution of organisms.  Ecological explanations are also considered.  Useful techniques for biogeographic analyses, such as comparison of area cladograms are discussed at length.

Application of ecological principles at the community level to marine benthic environments.  Discussion of community structure, animal-sediment relationships, roles of benthic communities in marine ecosystems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of community structure in marine environments
Knowledge of animal-sediment relationships in benthic environments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with other researchers in the field of marine ecology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying the roles of benthic communities in marine ecosystems
Developing research questions based on community structure analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading research projects focused on marine benthic ecology
Organizing fieldwork expeditions to study benthic environments

courseTitle: Phylogeny and Molecular Lecture and Laboratory
courseDescription: This course is intended to be an introduction to the processes and procedures used to reconstruct the evolutionary history of living organisms.  Topics include project planning, sampling strategies, molecular techniques, and analytical and tree-building programs used to infer phylogeny.  Lab provides computer experience in multiple phylogenetic software packages.
Current molecular understanding of genetic processes will be reviewed.  Applications to areas such as development and evolution will also be covered.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading lab team in genetic experiments

courseDescription: This course is intended to be an introduction to the processes and procedures used to reconstruct the evolutionary history of living organisms.  Topics include project planning, sampling strategies, molecular techniques, and analytical and tree-building programs used to infer phylogeny.  Lab provides computer experience in multiple phylogenetic software packages.

A ﬁrst course, or a refresher course, in statistical methods and experimental design for graduate students in biology and the natural sciences. The focus is on application and hypothesis testing with examples drawn from the ﬁeld of biology. The course requires a significant amount of work outside of class on homework exercises and an independent project.

Scientist are increasingly using molecular methods to help them address fundamental questions in the population ecology and evolution of biological species.  This class will introduce graduate students to the basic concepts and methods in molecular evolution, phylogenetics and methods into their research.  Theory and concepts from lecture will be illustrated through reading and discussion of current scientific literature.  Students will also directly apply the course material to a class project investigating population structure of marine species from the tropical Indo-Pacific, for which they will be trained in methods of DNA extraction, PCR and sequencing.  They will present their results orally in a mini-symposium at the end of the course.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating group work for mini-symposium presentation

courseDescription: A survey of the seminal ideas and perspectives in historical and contemporary ecology.  The course is designed to provide a broad overview of the important theoretical and conceptual paradigms in ecology.

This course will cover the field of environmental restoration guided by ecological theory and empirical research and connects with many broad themes in ecology, including physiology, genomics, biodiversity, conservation, species dispersal and migration, and population dynamics. This course will cover underlying principles guiding successful restoration, foundational and recent empirical research in this field, and restoration policies and practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Species dispersal and migration analysis in restoration
Population dynamics modeling for restoration projects
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of restoration goals and outcomes
Collaboration with stakeholders in restoration projects
Presenting restoration plans to diverse audiences
Negotiation skills in restoration policy discussions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of empirical research in restoration ecology
Designing successful restoration strategies based on ecological principles
Identifying key challenges in restoration projects and proposing solutions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating multiple aspects of restoration projects
Managing resources effectively in restoration initiatives

courseDescription: Under the guidance of members of the graduate faculty and with the approval of the program track coordinator, the student will carry out in-depth studies of selected topics relevant to the area of specialization.  Extensive surveys and analyses of the literature. Written reviews, comprehensive and synoptic, and oral presentations are required of each student.

Study of the role of insects, ticks and other invertebrates in the transmission of disease.  Different areas of disease transmission will be examined, including physiological and biochemical aspects of microbial survival in the vector and transmission to vertebrate hosts, as well as ecological aspects.

courseTitle: Modeling and Simulation in the Life Sciences
courseDescription: Course is designed to introduce students to modeling and simulation techniques using examples and applications in the life sciences.

courseTitle: Grant Writing for the Life Sciences
courseDescription: Provides students with the skills to write competetive grant proposals to both private and federal funding sources (emphasis on NIH and NSF).  Students will learn how to find the most appropriate funding mechanisms and how to position themselves to be competetive.  Different grant writing formats will be illustrated through proposal development projects.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Positioning oneself competitively for grant opportunities

courseDescription: Major research advances in immunology have resulted in substantially increasing the understanding of the molecular and cellular basis of autoimmune diseases and transplantation.  The course will focus on these new advances to improve the understanding of these diseases.  Topics will include a brief review of the immune system; multiple sclerosis, arthritis and other immune diseases; and the molecular and cellular basis of transplantation and chronic rejection of organ grafts.

courseDescription: This course is intended to be an introduction to the processes and procedures used to reconstruct the evolutionary history of living organisms.  Topics include project planning, sampling strategies, molecular techniques, and analytical and tree-building programs used to infer phylogeny.  Lab provides computer experience in multiple phylogenetic software packages.

A ﬁrst course, or a refresher course, in statistical methods and experimental design for graduate students in biology and the natural sciences. The focus is on application and hypothesis testing with examples drawn from the ﬁeld of biology. The course requires a significant amount of work outside of class on homework exercises and an independent project.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for outside class work

courseDescription: Scientist are increasingly using molecular methods to help them address fundamental questions in the population ecology and evolution of biological species.  This class will introduce graduate students to the basic concepts and methods in molecular evolution, phylogenetics and methods into their research.  Theory and concepts from lecture will be illustrated through reading and discussion of current scientific literature.  Students will also directly apply the course material to a class project investigating population structure of marine species from the tropical Indo-Pacific, for which they will be trained in methods of DNA extraction, PCR and sequencing.  They will present their results orally in a mini-symposium at the end of the course.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Presenting research findings in a mini-symposium

courseDescription: A survey of the seminal ideas and perspectives in historical and contemporary ecology.  The course is designed to provide a broad overview of the important theoretical and conceptual paradigms in ecology.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effectively communicating ecological concepts to non-specialists
Collaborating with interdisciplinary teams in research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying statistical methods to ecological data
Critical evaluation of ecological research findings

courseDescription: Internship experience.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using R or Python
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective teamwork in field research settings
Clear and concise scientific report writing
Oral presentation of research findings to diverse audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of ecological patterns and trends
Experimental design for ecological research projects
Troubleshooting equipment malfunctions in field settings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for ecological research studies
Supervision of research assistants or volunteers

courseDescription: This course will cover the field of environmental restoration guided by ecological theory and empirical research and connects with many broad themes in ecology, including physiology, genomics, biodiversity, conservation, species dispersal and migration, and population dynamics. This course will cover underlying principles guiding successful restoration, foundational and recent empirical research in this field, and restoration policies and practice.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with diverse stakeholders in restoration projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data interpretation for restoration outcomes analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for successful restoration projects

courseDescription: Study of the role of insects, ticks and other invertebrates in the transmission of disease.  Different areas of disease transmission will be examined, including physiological and biochemical aspects of microbial survival in the vector and transmission to vertebrate hosts, as well as ecological aspects.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of GIS technology for mapping disease spread
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective collaboration with researchers and field workers
Clear and concise reporting of findings to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data on vector populations and disease prevalence
Identifying factors contributing to disease transmission
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing and implementing disease control strategies in communities

courseTitle: Modeling and Simulation in Life Sciences
courseDescription: Course is designed to introduce students to modeling and simulation techniques using examples and applications in the life sciences.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in modeling and simulation

courseTitle: Grant Writing for the Life Sciences
courseDescription: Provides students with the skills to write competetive grant proposals to both private and federal funding sources (emphasis on NIH and NSF).  Students will learn how to find the most appropriate funding mechanisms and how to position themselves to be competetive.  Different grant writing formats will be illustrated through proposal development projects.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding NIH and NSF grant formats
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members on proposal development projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for grant proposal timelines

courseDescription: Under the guidance of members of the graduate faculty and with the approval of the program track coordinator, the student will carry out in-depth studies of selected topics relevant to the area of specialization.  Extensive surveys and analyses of the literature.  Written reviews, comprehensive and synoptic, and oral presentations are required of each student.

Major research advances in immunology have resulted in substantially increasing the understanding of the molecular and cellular basis of autoimmune diseases and transplantation.  The course will focus on these new advances to improve the understanding of these diseases.  Topics will include a brief review of the immune system; multiple sclerosis, arthritis and other immune diseases; and the molecular and cellular basis of transplantation and chronic rejection of organ grafts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding molecular and cellular basis of autoimmune diseases and transplantation
Familiarity with chronic rejection of organ grafts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings on autoimmune diseases and transplantation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing research data related to autoimmune diseases and transplantation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research projects related to autoimmune diseases and transplantation
Coordinating collaborative efforts in immunology research

courseDescription: An intense study of all systems from a regional approach. Extensive dissections required in lab. Clinical applications utilized.
Doctoral students in the Biomedical Sciences program will attend seminars, learn how to properly give a seminar, and present a seminar on their own research.
Study of special topics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on research projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on scientific topics

Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis using R or Python
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex biological concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of patterns in biological data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Delegating tasks within a research team

Technical and Digital Skills: Information security measures for data protection
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating research progress to advisors and peers
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Supervising research assistants or team members

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation. All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
